â€œSomething old,â€ said the gentleman. â€œTake my hat down for a moment from that peg, will you? No, I donâ€™t want it; look into it. What do you see written there?â€
The waiter read: â€œDatchery.â€

â€œNow you know my name,â€ said the gentleman; â€œDick Datchery. Hang it up again. I was saying something old is what I should prefer, something odd and out of the way; something venerable, architectural, and inconvenient.â€

â€œWe have a good choice of inconvenient lodgings in the town, sir, I think,â€ replied the waiter, with modest confidence in its resources that way; â€œindeed, I have no doubt that we could suit you that far, however particular you might be. But a architectural lodging!â€ That seemed to trouble the waiterâ€™s head, and he shook it.
â€œAnything Cathedraly, now,â€ Mr. Datchery suggested.
â€œMr. Tope,â€ said the waiter, brightening, as he rubbed his chin with his hand, â€œwould be the likeliest party to inform in that line.â€
â€œWho is Mr. Tope?â€ inquired Dick Datchery.

The waiter explained that he was the Verger, and that Mrs. Tope had indeed once upon a time let lodgings herself or offered to let them; but that as nobody had ever taken them, Mrs. Topeâ€™s window-bill, long a Cloisterham Institution, had disappeared; probably had tumbled down one day, and never been put up again.
â€œIâ€™ll call on Mrs. Tope,â€ said Mr. Datchery, â€œafter dinner.â€

So when he had done his dinner, he was duly directed to the spot, and sallied out for it. But the Crozier being an hotel of a most retiring disposition, and the waiterâ€™s directions being fatally precise, he soon became bewildered, and went boggling about and about the Cathedral Tower, whenever he could catch a glimpse of it, with a general impression on his mind that Mrs. Topeâ€™s was somewhere very near it, and that, like the children in the game of hot boiled beans and very good butter, he was warm in his search when he saw the Tower, and cold when he didnâ€™t see it.

He was getting very cold indeed when he came upon a fragment of burial-ground in which an unhappy sheep was grazing. Unhappy, because a hideous small boy was stoning it through the railings, and had already lamed it in one leg, and was much excited by the benevolent sportsmanlike purpose of breaking its other three legs, and bringing it down.
â€œâ€™It â€™im agin!â€ cried the boy, as the poor creature leaped; â€œand made a dint in his wool.â€
â€œLet him be!â€ said Mr. Datchery. â€œDonâ€™t you see you have lamed him?â€
â€œYer lie,â€ returned the sportsman. â€œâ€™E went and lamed isself. I see â€™im do it, and I givâ€™ â€™im a shy as a Widdy-warning to â€™im not to go a-bruisinâ€™ â€™is masterâ€™s mutton any more.â€
â€œCome here.â€
â€œI wonâ€™t; Iâ€™ll come when yer can ketch me.â€
â€œStay there then, and show me which is Mr. Topeâ€™s.â€
â€œOw can I stay here and show you which is Topeseses, when Topeseses is tâ€™other side the Kinfreederal, and over the crossings, and round ever so many comers? Stoo-pid! Ya-a-ah!â€
â€œShow me where it is, and Iâ€™ll give you something.â€
â€œCome on, then.â€
This brisk dialogue concluded, the boy led the way, and by-and-by stopped at some distance from an arched passage, pointing.
â€œLookie yonder. You see that there winder and door?â€
â€œThatâ€™s Topeâ€™s?â€
â€œYer lie; it ainâ€™t. Thatâ€™s Jarsperâ€™s.â€
â€œIndeed?â€ said Mr. Datchery, with a second look of some interest.
â€œYes, and I ainâ€™t a-goinâ€™ no nearer IM, I tell yer.â€
â€œWhy not?â€

â€œâ€™Cos I ainâ€™t a-goinâ€™ to be lifted off my legs and â€™ave my braces bust and be choked; not if I knows it, and not by â€œIm. Wait till I set a jolly good flint a-flyinâ€™ at the back oâ€™ â€™is jolly old â€™ed some day! Now look tâ€™other side the harch; not the side where Jarsperâ€™s door is; tâ€™other side.â€
â€œI see.â€
â€œA little way in, oâ€™ that side, thereâ€™s a low door, down two steps. Thatâ€™s Topeseses with â€™is name on a hoval plate.â€
â€œGood. See here,â€ said Mr. Datchery, producing a shilling. â€œYou owe me half of this.â€
â€œYer lie! I donâ€™t owe yer nothing; I never seen yer.â€
â€œI tell you you owe me half of this, because I have no sixpence in my pocket. So the next time you meet me you shall do something else for me, to pay me.â€
â€œAll right, give us â€™old.â€
â€œWhat is your name, and where do you live?â€
â€œDeputy. Travellersâ€™ Twopenny, â€™cross the green.â€

The boy instantly darted off with the shilling, lest Mr. Datchery should repent, but stopped at a safe distance, on the happy chance of his being uneasy in his mind about it, to goad him with a demon dance expressive of its irrevocability.
Mr. Datchery, taking off his hat to give that shock of white hair of his another shake, seemed quite resigned, and betook himself whither he had been directed.

Mr. Topeâ€™s official dwelling, communicating by an upper stair with Mr. Jasperâ€™s (hence Mrs. Topeâ€™s attendance on that gentleman), was of very modest proportions, and partook of the character of a cool dungeon. Its ancient walls were massive, and its rooms rather seemed to have been dug out of them, than to have been designed beforehand with any reference to them. The main door opened at once on a chamber of no describable shape, with a groined roof, which in its turn opened on another chamber of no describable shape, with another groined roof: their windows small, and in the thickness of the walls. These two chambers, close as to their atmosphere, and swarthy as to their illumination by natural light, were the apartments which Mrs. Tope had so long offered to an unappreciative city. Mr. Datchery, however, was more appreciative. He found that if he sat with the main door open he would enjoy the passing society of all comers to and fro by the gateway, and would have light enough. He found that if Mr. and Mrs. Tope, living overhead, used for their own egress and ingress a little side stair that came plump into the Precincts by a door opening outward, to the surprise and inconvenience of a limited public of pedestrians in a narrow way, he would be alone, as in a separate residence. He found the rent moderate, and everything as quaintly inconvenient as he could desire. He agreed, therefore, to take the lodging then and there, and money down, possession to be had next evening, on condition that reference was permitted him to Mr. Jasper as occupying the gatehouse, of which on the other side of the gateway, the Vergerâ€™s hole-in-the-wall was an appanage or subsidiary part.

The poor dear gentleman was very solitary and very sad, Mrs. Tope said, but she had no doubt he would â€œspeak for her.â€ Perhaps Mr. Datchery had heard something of what had occurred there last winter?

Mr. Datchery had as confused a knowledge of the event in question, on trying to recall it, as he well could have. He begged Mrs. Topeâ€™s pardon when she found it incumbent on her to correct him in every detail of his summary of the facts, but pleaded that he was merely a single buffer getting through life upon his means as idly as he could, and that so many people were so constantly making away with so many other people, as to render it difficult for a buffer of an easy temper to preserve the circumstances of the several cases unmixed in his mind.

Mr. Jasper proving willing to speak for Mrs. Tope, Mr. Datchery, who had sent up his card, was invited to ascend the postern staircase. The Mayor was there, Mr. Tope said; but he was not to be regarded in the light of company, as he and Mr. Jasper were great friends.

â€œI beg pardon,â€ said Mr. Datchery, making a leg with his hat under his arm, as he addressed himself equally to both gentlemen; â€œa selfish precaution on my part, and not personally interesting to anybody but myself. But as a buffer living on his means, and having an idea of doing it in this lovely place in peace and quiet, for remaining span of life, I beg to ask if the Tope family are quite respectable?â€
Mr. Jasper could answer for that without the slightest hesitation.
â€œThat is enough, sir,â€ said Mr. Datchery.

â€œMy friend the Mayor,â€ added Mr. Jasper, presenting Mr. Datchery with a courtly motion of his hand towards that potentate; â€œwhose recommendation is actually much more important to a stranger than that of an obscure person like myself, will testify in their behalf, I am sure.â€
â€œThe Worshipful the Mayor,â€ said Mr. Datchery, with a low bow, â€œplaces me under an infinite obligation.â€
â€œVery good people, sir, Mr. and Mrs. Tope,â€ said Mr. Sapsea, with condescension. â€œVery good opinions. Very well behaved. Very respectful. Much approved by the Dean and Chapter.â€

â€œThe Worshipful the Mayor gives them a character,â€ said Mr. Datchery, â€œof which they may indeed be proud. I would ask His Honour (if I might be permitted) whether there are not many objects of great interest in the city which is under his beneficent sway?â€

â€œWe are, sir,â€ returned Mr. Sapsea, â€œan ancient city, and an ecclesiastical city. We are a constitutional city, as it becomes such a city to be, and we uphold and maintain our glorious privileges.â€
â€œHis Honour,â€ said Mr. Datchery, bowing, â€œinspires me with a desire to know more of the city, and confirms me in my inclination to end my days in the city.â€
â€œRetired from the Army, sir?â€ suggested Mr. Sapsea.
â€œHis Honour the Mayor does me too much credit,â€ returned Mr. Datchery.
â€œNavy, sir?â€ suggested Mr. Sapsea.
â€œAgain,â€ repeated Mr. Datchery, â€œHis Honour the Mayor does me too much credit.â€
â€œDiplomacy is a fine profession,â€ said Mr. Sapsea, as a general remark.
â€œThere, I confess, His Honour the Mayor is too many for me,â€ said Mr. Datchery, with an ingenious smile and bow; â€œeven a diplomatic bird must fall to such a gun.â€

Now this was very soothing. Here was a gentleman of a great, not to say a grand, address, accustomed to rank and dignity, really setting a fine example how to behave to a Mayor. There was something in that third-person style of being spoken to, that Mr. Sapsea found particularly recognisant of his merits and position.

â€œBut I crave pardon,â€ said Mr. Datchery. â€œHis Honour the Mayor will bear with me, if for a moment I have been deluded into occupying his time, and have forgotten the humble claims upon my own, of my hotel, the Crozier.â€
â€œNot at all, sir,â€ said Mr. Sapsea. â€œI am returning home, and if you would like to take the exterior of our Cathedral in your way, I shall be glad to point it out.â€
â€œHis Honour the Mayor,â€ said Mr. Datchery, â€œis more than kind and gracious.â€

As Mr. Datchery, when he had made his acknowledgments to Mr. Jasper, could not be induced to go out of the room before the Worshipful, the Worshipful led the way down-stairs; Mr. Datchery following with his hat under his arm, and his shock of white hair streaming in the evening breeze.

â€œMight I ask His Honour,â€ said Mr. Datchery, â€œwhether that gentleman we have just left is the gentleman of whom I have heard in the neighbourhood as being much afflicted by the loss of a nephew, and concentrating his life on avenging the loss?â€
â€œThat is the gentleman. John Jasper, sir.â€
â€œWould His Honour allow me to inquire whether there are strong suspicions of any one?â€
â€œMore than suspicions, sir,â€ returned Mr. Sapsea; â€œall but certainties.â€
â€œOnly think now!â€ cried Mr. Datchery.

â€œBut proof, sir, proof must be built up stone by stone,â€ said the Mayor. â€œAs I say, the end crowns the work. It is not enough that justice should be morally certain; she must be immorally certainâ€”legally, that is.â€
â€œHis Honour,â€ said Mr. Datchery, â€œreminds me of the nature of the law. Immoral. How true!â€
â€œAs I say, sir,â€ pompously went on the Mayor, â€œthe arm of the law is a strong arm, and a long arm. That is the way I put it. A strong arm and a long arm.â€
â€œHow forcible!â€”And yet, again, how true!â€ murmured Mr. Datchery.
â€œAnd without betraying, what I call the secrets of the prison-house,â€ said Mr. Sapsea; â€œthe secrets of the prison-house is the term I used on the bench.â€
â€œAnd what other term than His Honourâ€™s would express it?â€ said Mr. Datchery.

â€œWithout, I say, betraying them, I predict to you, knowing the iron will of the gentleman we have just left (I take the bold step of calling it iron, on account of its strength), that in this case the long arm will reach, and the strong arm will strike.â€”This is our Cathedral, sir. The best judges are pleased to admire it, and the best among our townsmen own to being a little vain of it.â€

All this time Mr. Datchery had walked with his hat under his arm, and his white hair streaming. He had an odd momentary appearance upon him of having forgotten his hat, when Mr. Sapsea now touched it; and he clapped his hand up to his head as if with some vague expectation of finding another hat upon it.
â€œPray be covered, sir,â€ entreated Mr. Sapsea; magnificently plying: â€œI shall not mind it, I assure you.â€
â€œHis Honour is very good, but I do it for coolness,â€ said Mr. Datchery.

Then Mr. Datchery admired the Cathedral, and Mr. Sapsea pointed it out as if he himself had invented and built it: there were a few details indeed of which he did not approve, but those he glossed over, as if the workmen had made mistakes in his absence. The Cathedral disposed of, he led the way by the churchyard, and stopped to extol the beauty of the eveningâ€”by chanceâ€”in the immediate vicinity of Mrs. Sapseaâ€™s epitaph.

â€œAnd by the by,â€ said Mr. Sapsea, appearing to descend from an elevation to remember it all of a sudden; like Apollo shooting down from Olympus to pick up his forgotten lyre; â€œthat is one of our small lions. The partiality of our people has made it so, and strangers have been seen taking a copy of it now and then. I am not a judge of it myself, for it is a little work of my own. But it was troublesome to turn, sir; I may say, difficult to turn with elegance.â€

Mr. Datchery became so ecstatic over Mr. Sapseaâ€™s composition, that, in spite of his intention to end his days in Cloisterham, and therefore his probably having in reserve many opportunities of copying it, he would have transcribed it into his pocket-book on the spot, but for the slouching towards them of its material producer and perpetuator, Durdles, whom Mr. Sapsea hailed, not sorry to show him a bright example of behaviour to superiors.
â€œAh, Durdles! This is the mason, sir; one of our Cloisterham worthies; everybody here knows Durdles. Mr. Datchery, Durdles a gentleman who is going to settle here.â€
â€œI wouldnâ€™t do it if I was him,â€ growled Durdles. â€œWeâ€™re a heavy lot.â€
â€œYou surely donâ€™t speak for yourself, Mr. Durdles,â€ returned Mr. Datchery, â€œany more than for His Honour.â€
â€œWhoâ€™s His Honour?â€ demanded Durdles.
â€œHis Honour the Mayor.â€

â€œI never was brought afore him,â€ said Durdles, with anything but the look of a loyal subject of the mayoralty, â€œand itâ€™ll be time enough for me to Honour him when I am. Until which, and when, and where,

â€˜Mister Sapsea is his name,
Â Â Â Â England is his nation,
Cloisterhamâ€™s his dwelling-place,
Â Â Â Â Aukshneerâ€™s his occupation.â€™â€

Here, Deputy (preceded by a flying oyster-shell) appeared upon the scene, and requested to have the sum of threepence instantly â€œchuckedâ€ to him by Mr. Durdles, whom he had been vainly seeking up and down, as lawful wages overdue. While that gentleman, with his bundle under his arm, slowly found and counted out the money, Mr. Sapsea informed the new settler of Durdlesâ€™s habits, pursuits, abode, and reputation. â€œI suppose a curious stranger might come to see you, and your works, Mr. Durdles, at any odd time?â€ said Mr. Datchery upon that.

â€œAny gentleman is welcome to come and see me any evening if he brings liquor for two with him,â€ returned Durdles, with a penny between his teeth and certain halfpence in his hands; â€œor if he likes to make it twice two, heâ€™ll be doubly welcome.â€
â€œI shall come. Master Deputy, what do you owe me?â€
â€œA job.â€
â€œMind you pay me honestly with the job of showing me Mr. Durdlesâ€™s house when I want to go there.â€
Deputy, with a piercing broadside of whistle through the whole gap in his mouth, as a receipt in full for all arrears, vanished.

The Worshipful and the Worshipper then passed on together until they parted, with many ceremonies, at the Worshipfulâ€™s door; even then the Worshipper carried his hat under his arm, and gave his streaming white hair to the breeze.

Said Mr. Datchery to himself that night, as he looked at his white hair in the gas-lighted looking-glass over the coffee-room chimneypiece at the Crozier, and shook it out: â€œFor a single buffer, of an easy temper, living idly on his means, I have had a rather busy afternoon!â€

div.head:
CHAPTER XIX.
SHADOW ON THE SUN-DIAL
div.p: Again Miss Twinkleton has delivered her valedictory address, with the accompaniments of white-wine and pound-cake, and again the young ladies have departed to their several homes. Helena Landless has left the Nunsâ€™ House to attend her brotherâ€™s fortunes, and pretty Rosa is alone.

Cloisterham is so bright and sunny in these summer days, that the Cathedral and the monastery-ruin show as if their strong walls were transparent. A soft glow seems to shine from within them, rather than upon them from without, such is their mellowness as they look forth on the hot corn-fields and the smoking roads that distantly wind among them. The Cloisterham gardens blush with ripening fruit. Time was when travel-stained pilgrims rode in clattering parties through the cityâ€™s welcome shades; time is when wayfarers, leading a gipsy life between haymaking time and harvest, and looking as if they were just made of the dust of the earth, so very dusty are they, lounge about on cool door-steps, trying to mend their unmendable shoes, or giving them to the city kennels as a hopeless job, and seeking others in the bundles that they carry, along with their yet unused sickles swathed in bands of straw. At all the more public pumps there is much cooling of bare feet, together with much bubbling and gurgling of drinking with hand to spout on the part of these Bedouins; the Cloisterham police meanwhile looking askant from their beats with suspicion, and manifest impatience that the intruders should depart from within the civic bounds, and once more fry themselves on the simmering high-roads.

On the afternoon of such a day, when the last Cathedral service is done, and when that side of the High Street on which the Nunsâ€™ House stands is in grateful shade, save where its quaint old garden opens to the west between the boughs of trees, a servant informs Rosa, to her terror, that Mr. Jasper desires to see her.

If he had chosen his time for finding her at a disadvantage, he could have done no better. Perhaps he has chosen it. Helena Landless is gone, Mrs. Tisher is absent on leave, Miss Twinkleton (in her amateur state of existence) has contributed herself and a veal pie to a picnic.
â€œO why, why, why, did you say I was at home!â€ cried Rosa, helplessly.
The maid replies, that Mr. Jasper never asked the question.
That he said he knew she was at home, and begged she might be told that he asked to see her.
â€œWhat shall I do! what shall I do!â€ thinks Rosa, clasping her hands.

Possessed by a kind of desperation, she adds in the next breath, that she will come to Mr. Jasper in the garden. She shudders at the thought of being shut up with him in the house; but many of its windows command the garden, and she can be seen as well as heard there, and can shriek in the free air and run away. Such is the wild idea that flutters through her mind.

She has never seen him since the fatal night, except when she was questioned before the Mayor, and then he was present in gloomy watchfulness, as representing his lost nephew and burning to avenge him. She hangs her garden-hat on her arm, and goes out. The moment she sees him from the porch, leaning on the sun-dial, the old horrible feeling of being compelled by him, asserts its hold upon her. She feels that she would even then go back, but that he draws her feet towards him. She cannot resist, and sits down, with her head bent, on the garden-seat beside the sun-dial. She cannot look up at him for abhorrence, but she has perceived that he is dressed in deep mourning. So is she. It was not so at first; but the lost has long been given up, and mourned for, as dead.
He would begin by touching her hand. She feels the intention, and draws her hand back. His eyes are then fixed upon her, she knows, though her own see nothing but the grass.
â€œI have been waiting,â€ he begins, â€œfor some time, to be summoned back to my duty near you.â€
After several times forming her lips, which she knows he is closely watching, into the shape of some other hesitating reply, and then into none, she answers: â€œDuty, sir?â€
â€œThe duty of teaching you, serving you as your faithful music-master.â€
â€œI have left off that study.â€
â€œNot left off, I think. Discontinued. I was told by your guardian that you discontinued it under the shock that we have all felt so acutely. When will you resume?â€
â€œNever, sir.â€
â€œNever? You could have done no more if you had loved my dear boy.â€
â€œI did love him!â€ cried Rosa, with a flash of anger.

â€œYes; but not quiteâ€”not quite in the right way, shall I say? Not in the intended and expected way. Much as my dear boy was, unhappily, too self-conscious and self-satisfied (Iâ€™ll draw no parallel between him and you in that respect) to love as he should have loved, or as any one in his place would have lovedâ€”must have loved!â€
She sits in the same still attitude, but shrinking a little more.
â€œThen, to be told that you discontinued your study with me, was to be politely told that you abandoned it altogether?â€ he suggested.
â€œYes,â€ says Rosa, with sudden spirit, â€œThe politeness was my guardianâ€™s, not mine. I told him that I was resolved to leave off, and that I was determined to stand by my resolution.â€
â€œAnd you still are?â€
â€œI still am, sir. And I beg not to be questioned any more about it. At all events, I will not answer any more; I have that in my power.â€

She is so conscious of his looking at her with a gloating admiration of the touch of anger on her, and the fire and animation it brings with it, that even as her spirit rises, it falls again, and she struggles with a sense of shame, affront, and fear, much as she did that night at the piano.
â€œI will not question you any more, since you object to it so much; I will confessâ€”â€
â€œI do not wish to hear you, sir,â€ cries Rosa, rising.
This time he does touch her with his outstretched hand. In shrinking from it, she shrinks into her seat again.
â€œWe must sometimes act in opposition to our wishes,â€ he tells her in a low voice. â€œYou must do so now, or do more harm to others than you can ever set right.â€
â€œWhat harm?â€
â€œPresently, presently. You question me, you see, and surely thatâ€™s not fair when you forbid me to question you. Nevertheless, I will answer the question presently. Dearest Rosa! Charming Rosa!â€
She starts up again.

This time he does not touch her. But his face looks so wicked and menacing, as he stands leaning against the sun-dial-setting, as it were, his black mark upon the very face of dayâ€”that her flight is arrested by horror as she looks at him.

â€œI do not forget how many windows command a view of us,â€ he says, glancing towards them. â€œI will not touch you again; I will come no nearer to you than I am. Sit down, and there will be no mighty wonder in your music-masterâ€™s leaning idly against a pedestal and speaking with you, remembering all that has happened, and our shares in it. Sit down, my beloved.â€

She would have gone once moreâ€”was all but goneâ€”and once more his face, darkly threatening what would follow if she went, has stopped her. Looking at him with the expression of the instant frozen on her face, she sits down on the seat again.

â€œRosa, even when my dear boy was affianced to you, I loved you madly; even when I thought his happiness in having you for his wife was certain, I loved you madly; even when I strove to make him more ardently devoted to you, I loved you madly; even when he gave me the picture of your lovely face so carelessly traduced by him, which I feigned to hang always in my sight for his sake, but worshipped in torment for years, I loved you madly; in the distasteful work of the day, in the wakeful misery of the night, girded by sordid realities, or wandering through Paradises and Hells of visions into which I rushed, carrying your image in my arms, I loved you madly.â€
If anything could make his words more hideous to her than they are in themselves, it would be the contrast between the violence of his look and delivery, and the composure of his assumed attitude.
â€œI endured it all in silence. So long as you were his, or so long as I supposed you to be his, I hid my secret loyally. Did I not?â€

This lie, so gross, while the mere words in which it is told are so true, is more than Rosa can endure. She answers with kindling indignation: â€œYou were as false throughout, sir, as you are now. You were false to him, daily and hourly. You know that you made my life unhappy by your pursuit of me. You know that you made me afraid to open his generous eyes, and that you forced me, for his own trusting, good, good sake, to keep the truth from him, that you were a bad, bad man!â€
His preservation of his easy attitude rendering his working features and his convulsive hands absolutely diabolical, he returns, with a fierce extreme of admiration:

â€œHow beautiful you are! You are more beautiful in anger than in repose. I donâ€™t ask you for your love; give me yourself and your hatred; give me yourself and that pretty rage; give me yourself and that enchanting scorn; it will be enough for me.â€

Impatient tears rise to the eyes of the trembling little beauty, and her face flames; but as she again rises to leave him in indignation, and seek protection within the house, he stretches out his hand towards the porch, as though he invited her to enter it.
â€œI told you, you rare charmer, you sweet witch, that you must stay and hear me, or do more harm than can ever be undone. You asked me what harm. Stay, and I will tell you. Go, and I will do it!â€

Again Rosa quails before his threatening face, though innocent of its meaning, and she remains. Her panting breathing comes and goes as if it would choke her; but with a repressive hand upon her bosom, she remains.

â€œI have made my confession that my love is mad. It is so mad, that had the ties between me and my dear lost boy been one silken thread less strong, I might have swept even him from your side, when you favoured him.â€
A film comes over the eyes she raises for an instant, as though he had turned her faint.
â€œEven him,â€ he repeats. â€œYes, even him! Rosa, you see me and you hear me. Judge for yourself whether any other admirer shall love you and live, whose life is in my hand.â€
â€œWhat do you mean, sir?â€

â€œI mean to show you how mad my love is. It was hawked through the late inquiries by Mr. Crisparkle, that young Landless had confessed to him that he was a rival of my lost boy. That is an inexpiable offence in my eyes. The same Mr. Crisparkle knows under my hand that I have devoted myself to the murdererâ€™s discovery and destruction, be he whom he might, and that I determined to discuss the mystery with no one until I should hold the clue in which to entangle the murderer as in a net. I have since worked patiently to wind and wind it round him; and it is slowly winding as I speak.â€
Jasperâ€™s sacrifices
â€œYour belief, if you believe in the criminality of Mr. Landless, is not Mr. Crisparkleâ€™s belief, and he is a good man,â€ Rosa retorts.

â€œMy belief is my own; and I reserve it, worshipped of my soul! Circumstances may accumulate so strongly even against an innocent man, that directed, sharpened, and pointed, they may slay him. One wanting link discovered by perseverance against a guilty man, proves his guilt, however slight its evidence before, and he dies. Young Landless stands in deadly peril either way.â€
â€œIf you really suppose,â€ Rosa pleads with him, turning paler, â€œthat I favour Mr. Landless, or that Mr. Landless has ever in any way addressed himself to me, you are wrong.â€
He puts that from him with a slighting action of his hand and a curled lip.

â€œI was going to show you how madly I love you. More madly now than ever, for I am willing to renounce the second object that has arisen in my life to divide it with you; and henceforth to have no object in existence but you only. Miss Landless has become your bosom friend. You care for her peace of mind?â€
â€œI love her dearly.â€
â€œYou care for her good name?â€
â€œI have said, sir, I love her dearly.â€

â€œI am unconsciously,â€ he observes with a smile, as he folds his hands upon the sun-dial and leans his chin upon them, so that his talk would seem from the windows (faces occasionally come and go there) to be of the airiest and playfullestâ€”â€œI am unconsciously giving offence by questioning again. I will simply make statements, therefore, and not put questions. You do care for your bosom friendâ€™s good name, and you do care for her peace of mind. Then remove the shadow of the gallows from her, dear one!â€
â€œYou dare propose to me toâ€”â€

â€œDarling, I dare propose to you. Stop there. If it be bad to idolise you, I am the worst of men; if it be good, I am the best. My love for you is above all other love, and my truth to you is above all other truth. Let me have hope and favour, and I am a forsworn man for your sake.â€

Rosa puts her hands to her temples, and, pushing back her hair, looks wildly and abhorrently at him, as though she were trying to piece together what it is his deep purpose to present to her only in fragments.

â€œReckon up nothing at this moment, angel, but the sacrifices that I lay at those dear feet, which I could fall down among the vilest ashes and kiss, and put upon my head as a poor savage might. There is my fidelity to my dear boy after death. Tread upon it!â€
With an action of his hands, as though he cast down something precious.
â€œThere is the inexpiable offence against my adoration of you. Spurn it!â€
With a similar action.
â€œThere are my labours in the cause of a just vengeance for six toiling months. Crush them!â€
With another repetition of the action.

â€œThere is my past and my present wasted life. There is the desolation of my heart and my soul. There is my peace; there is my despair. Stamp them into the dust; so that you take me, were it even mortally hating me!â€

The frightful vehemence of the man, now reaching its full height, so additionally terrifies her as to break the spell that has held her to the spot. She swiftly moves towards the porch; but in an instant he is at her side, and speaking in her ear.
â€œRosa, I am self-repressed again. I am walking calmly beside you to the house. I shall wait for some encouragement and hope. I shall not strike too soon. Give me a sign that you attend to me.â€
She slightly and constrainedly moves her hand.
â€œNot a word of this to any one, or it will bring down the blow, as certainly as night follows day. Another sign that you attend to me.â€
She moves her hand once more.
â€œI love you, love you, love you! If you were to cast me off nowâ€”but you will notâ€”you would never be rid of me. No one should come between us. I would pursue you to the death.â€

The handmaid coming out to open the gate for him, he quietly pulls off his hat as a parting salute, and goes away with no greater show of agitation than is visible in the effigy of Mr. Sapseaâ€™s father opposite. Rosa faints in going up-stairs, and is carefully carried to her room and laid down on her bed. A thunderstorm is coming on, the maids say, and the hot and stifling air has overset the pretty dear: no wonder; they have felt their own knees all of a tremble all day long.

div.head:
CHAPTER XX.
A FLIGHT
div.p: Rosa no sooner came to herself than the whole of the late interview was before her. It even seemed as if it had pursued her into her insensibility, and she had not had a momentâ€™s unconsciousness of it. What to do, she was at a frightened loss to know: the only one clear thought in her mind was, that she must fly from this terrible man.

But where could she take refuge, and how could she go? She had never breathed her dread of him to any one but Helena. If she went to Helena, and told her what had passed, that very act might bring down the irreparable mischief that he threatened he had the power, and that she knew he had the will, to do. The more fearful he appeared to her excited memory and imagination, the more alarming her responsibility appeared; seeing that a slight mistake on her part, either in action or delay, might let his malevolence loose on Helenaâ€™s brother.

Rosaâ€™s mind throughout the last six months had been stormily confused. A half-formed, wholly unexpressed suspicion tossed in it, now heaving itself up, and now sinking into the deep; now gaining palpability, and now losing it. Jasperâ€™s self-absorption in his nephew when he was alive, and his unceasing pursuit of the inquiry how he came by his death, if he were dead, were themes so rife in the place, that no one appeared able to suspect the possibility of foul play at his hands. She had asked herself the question, â€œAm I so wicked in my thoughts as to conceive a wickedness that others cannot imagine?â€ Then she had considered, Did the suspicion come of her previous recoiling from him before the fact? And if so, was not that a proof of its baselessness? Then she had reflected, â€œWhat motive could he have, according to my accusation?â€ She was ashamed to answer in her mind, â€œThe motive of gaining me!â€ And covered her face, as if the lightest shadow of the idea of founding murder on such an idle vanity were a crime almost as great.

She ran over in her mind again, all that he had said by the sun-dial in the garden. He had persisted in treating the disappearance as murder, consistently with his whole public course since the finding of the watch and shirt-pin. If he were afraid of the crime being traced out, would he not rather encourage the idea of a voluntary disappearance? He had even declared that if the ties between him and his nephew had been less strong, he might have swept â€œeven himâ€ away from her side. Was that like his having really done so? He had spoken of laying his six monthsâ€™ labours in the cause of a just vengeance at her feet. Would he have done that, with that violence of passion, if they were a pretence? Would he have ranged them with his desolate heart and soul, his wasted life, his peace and his despair? The very first sacrifice that he represented himself as making for her, was his fidelity to his dear boy after death. Surely these facts were strong against a fancy that scarcely dared to hint itself. And yet he was so terrible a man! In short, the poor girl (for what could she know of the criminal intellect, which its own professed students perpetually misread, because they persist in trying to reconcile it with the average intellect of average men, instead of identifying it as a horrible wonder apart) could get by no road to any other conclusion than that he was a terrible man, and must be fled from.

She had been Helenaâ€™s stay and comfort during the whole time. She had constantly assured her of her full belief in her brotherâ€™s innocence, and of her sympathy with him in his misery. But she had never seen him since the disappearance, nor had Helena ever spoken one word of his avowal to Mr. Crisparkle in regard of Rosa, though as a part of the interest of the case it was well known far and wide. He was Helenaâ€™s unfortunate brother, to her, and nothing more. The assurance she had given her odious suitor was strictly true, though it would have been better (she considered now) if she could have restrained herself from so giving it. Afraid of him as the bright and delicate little creature was, her spirit swelled at the thought of his knowing it from her own lips.

But where was she to go? Anywhere beyond his reach, was no reply to the question. Somewhere must be thought of. She determined to go to her guardian, and to go immediately. The feeling she had imparted to Helena on the night of their first confidence, was so strong upon herâ€”the feeling of not being safe from him, and of the solid walls of the old convent being powerless to keep out his ghostly following of herâ€”that no reasoning of her own could calm her terrors. The fascination of repulsion had been upon her so long, and now culminated so darkly, that she felt as if he had power to bind her by a spell. Glancing out at window, even now, as she rose to dress, the sight of the sun-dial on which he had leaned when he declared himself, turned her cold, and made her shrink from it, as though he had invested it with some awful quality from his own nature.

She wrote a hurried note to Miss Twinkleton, saying that she had sudden reason for wishing to see her guardian promptly, and had gone to him; also, entreating the good lady not to be uneasy, for all was well with her. She hurried a few quite useless articles into a very little bag, left the note in a conspicuous place, and went out, softly closing the gate after her.

It was the first time she had ever been even in Cloisterham High Street alone. But knowing all its ways and windings very well, she hurried straight to the corner from which the omnibus departed. It was, at that very moment, going off.
â€œStop and take me, if you please, Joe. I am obliged to go to London.â€

In less than another minute she was on her road to the railway, under Joeâ€™s protection. Joe waited on her when she got there, put her safely into the railway carriage, and handed in the very little bag after her, as though it were some enormous trunk, hundredweights heavy, which she must on no account endeavour to lift.
â€œCan you go round when you get back, and tell Miss Twinkleton that you saw me safely off, Joe?â€
â€œIt shall be done, Miss.â€
â€œWith my love, please, Joe.â€
â€œYes, Missâ€”and I wouldnâ€™t mind having it myself!â€ But Joe did not articulate the last clause; only thought it.

Now that she was whirling away for London in real earnest, Rosa was at leisure to resume the thoughts which her personal hurry had checked. The indignant thought that his declaration of love soiled her; that she could only be cleansed from the stain of its impurity by appealing to the honest and true; supported her for a time against her fears, and confirmed her in her hasty resolution. But as the evening grew darker and darker, and the great city impended nearer and nearer, the doubts usual in such cases began to arise. Whether this was not a wild proceeding, after all; how Mr. Grewgious might regard it; whether she should find him at the journeyâ€™s end; how she would act if he were absent; what might become of her, alone, in a place so strange and crowded; how if she had but waited and taken counsel first; whether, if she could now go back, she would not do it thankfully; a multitude of such uneasy speculations disturbed her, more and more as they accumulated. At length the train came into London over the housetops; and down below lay the gritty streets with their yet un-needed lamps a-glow, on a hot, light, summer night.

â€œHiram Grewgious, Esquire, Staple Inn, London.â€ This was all Rosa knew of her destination; but it was enough to send her rattling away again in a cab, through deserts of gritty streets, where many people crowded at the corner of courts and byways to get some air, and where many other people walked with a miserably monotonous noise of shuffling of feet on hot paving-stones, and where all the people and all their surroundings were so gritty and so shabby!

There was music playing here and there, but it did not enliven the case. No barrel-organ mended the matter, and no big drum beat dull care away. Like the chapel bells that were also going here and there, they only seemed to evoke echoes from brick surfaces, and dust from everything. As to the flat wind-instruments, they seemed to have cracked their hearts and souls in pining for the country.

Her jingling conveyance stopped at last at a fast-closed gateway, which appeared to belong to somebody who had gone to bed very early, and was much afraid of housebreakers; Rosa, discharging her conveyance, timidly knocked at this gateway, and was let in, very little bag and all, by a watchman.
â€œDoes Mr. Grewgious live here?â€
â€œMr. Grewgious lives there, Miss,â€ said the watchman, pointing further in.
So Rosa went further in, and, when the clocks were striking ten, stood on P. J. T.â€s doorsteps, wondering what P. J. T. had done with his street-door.

Guided by the painted name of Mr. Grewgious, she went up-stairs and softly tapped and tapped several times. But no one answering, and Mr. Grewgiousâ€™s door-handle yielding to her touch, she went in, and saw her guardian sitting on a window-seat at an open window, with a shaded lamp placed far from him on a table in a corner.
Rosa drew nearer to him in the twilight of the room. He saw her, and he said, in an undertone: â€œGood Heaven!â€
Rosa fell upon his neck, with tears, and then he said, returning her embrace:
â€œMy child, my child! I thought you were your mother!â€”But what, what, what,â€ he added, soothingly, â€œhas happened? My dear, what has brought you here? Who has brought you here?â€
â€œNo one. I came alone.â€
â€œLord bless me!â€ ejaculated Mr. Grewgious. â€œCame alone! Why didnâ€™t you write to me to come and fetch you?â€
â€œI had no time. I took a sudden resolution. Poor, poor Eddy!â€
â€œAh, poor fellow, poor fellow!â€

â€œHis uncle has made love to me. I cannot bear it,â€ said Rosa, at once with a burst of tears, and a stamp of her little foot; â€œI shudder with horror of him, and I have come to you to protect me and all of us from him, if you will?â€
â€œI will,â€ cried Mr. Grewgious, with a sudden rush of amazing energy. â€œDamn him!

â€˜Confound his politics!
Frustrate his knavish tricks!
On Thee his hopes to fix?
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Damn him again!â€™â€

After this most extraordinary outburst, Mr. Grewgious, quite beside himself, plunged about the room, to all appearance undecided whether he was in a fit of loyal enthusiasm, or combative denunciation.

He stopped and said, wiping his face: â€œI beg your pardon, my dear, but you will be glad to know I feel better. Tell me no more just now, or I might do it again. You must be refreshed and cheered. What did you take last? Was it breakfast, lunch, dinner, tea, or supper? And what will you take next? Shall it be breakfast, lunch, dinner, tea, or supper?â€

The respectful tenderness with which, on one knee before her, he helped her to remove her hat, and disentangle her pretty hair from it, was quite a chivalrous sight. Yet who, knowing him only on the surface, would have expected chivalryâ€”and of the true sort, too; not the spuriousâ€”from Mr. Grewgious?

â€œYour rest too must be provided for,â€ he went on; â€œand you shall have the prettiest chamber in Furnivalâ€™s. Your toilet must be provided for, and you shall have everything that an unlimited head chambermaidâ€”by which expression I mean a head chambermaid not limited as to outlayâ€”can procure. Is that a bag?â€ he looked hard at it; sooth to say, it required hard looking at to be seen at all in a dimly lighted room: â€œand is it your property, my dear?â€
â€œYes, sir. I brought it with me.â€
â€œIt is not an extensive bag,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, candidly, â€œthough admirably calculated to contain a dayâ€™s provision for a canary-bird. Perhaps you brought a canary-bird?â€
Rosa smiled and shook her head.

â€œIf you had, he should have been made welcome,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œand I think he would have been pleased to be hung upon a nail outside and pit himself against our Staple sparrows; whose execution must be admitted to be not quite equal to their intention. Which is the case with so many of us! You didnâ€™t say what meal, my dear. Have a nice jumble of all meals.â€

Rosa thanked him, but said she could only take a cup of tea. Mr. Grewgious, after several times running out, and in again, to mention such supplementary items as marmalade, eggs, watercresses, salted fish, and frizzled ham, ran across to Furnivalâ€™s without his hat, to give his various directions. And soon afterwards they were realised in practice, and the board was spread.
â€œLord bless my soul,â€ cried Mr. Grewgious, putting the lamp upon it, and taking his seat opposite Rosa; â€œwhat a new sensation for a poor old Angular bachelor, to be sure!â€
Mr. Grewgious experiences a new sensation
Rosaâ€™s expressive little eyebrows asked him what he meant?
â€œThe sensation of having a sweet young presence in the place, that whitewashes it, paints it, papers it, decorates it with gilding, and makes it Glorious!â€ said Mr. Grewgious. â€œAh me! Ah me!â€
As there was something mournful in his sigh, Rosa, in touching him with her tea-cup, ventured to touch him with her small hand too.
â€œThank you, my dear,â€ said Mr. Grewgious. â€œAhem! Letâ€™s talk!â€
â€œDo you always live here, sir?â€ asked Rosa.
â€œYes, my dear.â€
â€œAnd always alone?â€
â€œAlways alone; except that I have daily company in a gentleman by the name of Bazzard, my clerk.â€
â€œHe doesnâ€™t live here?â€

â€œNo, he goes his way, after office hours. In fact, he is off duty here, altogether, just at present; and a firm down-stairs, with which I have business relations, lend me a substitute. But it would be extremely difficult to replace Mr. Bazzard.â€
â€œHe must be very fond of you,â€ said Rosa.

â€œHe bears up against it with commendable fortitude if he is,â€ returned Mr. Grewgious, after considering the matter. â€œBut I doubt if he is. Not particularly so. You see, he is discontented, poor fellow.â€
â€œWhy isnâ€™t he contented?â€ was the natural inquiry.
â€œMisplaced,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, with great mystery.
Rosaâ€™s eyebrows resumed their inquisitive and perplexed expression.
â€œSo misplaced,â€ Mr. Grewgious went on, â€œthat I feel constantly apologetic towards him. And he feels (though he doesnâ€™t mention it) that I have reason to be.â€
Mr. Grewgious had by this time grown so very mysterious, that Rosa did not know how to go on. While she was thinking about it Mr. Grewgious suddenly jerked out of himself for the second time:

â€œLetâ€™s talk. We were speaking of Mr. Bazzard. Itâ€™s a secret, and moreover it is Mr. Bazzardâ€™s secret; but the sweet presence at my table makes me so unusually expansive, that I feel I must impart it in inviolable confidence. What do you think Mr. Bazzard has done?â€
â€œO dear!â€ cried Rosa, drawing her chair a little nearer, and her mind reverting to Jasper, â€œnothing dreadful, I hope?â€
â€œHe has written a play,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, in a solemn whisper. â€œA tragedy.â€
Rosa seemed much relieved.
â€œAnd nobody,â€ pursued Mr. Grewgious in the same tone, â€œwill hear, on any account whatever, of bringing it out.â€
Rosa looked reflective, and nodded her head slowly; as who should say, â€œSuch things are, and why are they!â€
â€œNow, you know,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œI couldnâ€™t write a play.â€
â€œNot a bad one, sir?â€ said Rosa, innocently, with her eyebrows again in action.

â€œNo. If I was under sentence of decapitation, and was about to be instantly decapitated, and an express arrived with a pardon for the condemned convict Grewgious if he wrote a play, I should be under the necessity of resuming the block, and begging the executioner to proceed to extremities,â€”meaning,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, passing his hand under his chin, â€œthe singular number, and this extremity.â€
Rosa appeared to consider what she would do if the awkward supposititious case were hers.
â€œConsequently,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œMr. Bazzard would have a sense of my inferiority to himself under any circumstances; but when I am his master, you know, the case is greatly aggravated.â€
Mr. Grewgious shook his head seriously, as if he felt the offence to be a little too much, though of his own committing.
â€œHow came you to be his master, sir?â€ asked Rosa.

â€œA question that naturally follows,â€ said Mr. Grewgious. â€œLetâ€™s talk. Mr. Bazzardâ€™s father, being a Norfolk farmer, would have furiously laid about him with a flail, a pitch-fork, and every agricultural implement available for assaulting purposes, on the slightest hint of his sonâ€™s having written a play. So the son, bringing to me the fatherâ€™s rent (which I receive), imparted his secret, and pointed out that he was determined to pursue his genius, and that it would put him in peril of starvation, and that he was not formed for it.â€
â€œFor pursuing his genius, sir?â€

â€œNo, my dear,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œfor starvation. It was impossible to deny the position, that Mr. Bazzard was not formed to be starved, and Mr. Bazzard then pointed out that it was desirable that I should stand between him and a fate so perfectly unsuited to his formation. In that way Mr. Bazzard became my clerk, and he feels it very much.â€
â€œI am glad he is grateful,â€ said Rosa.

â€œI didnâ€™t quite mean that, my dear. I mean, that he feels the degradation. There are some other geniuses that Mr. Bazzard has become acquainted with, who have also written tragedies, which likewise nobody will on any account whatever hear of bringing out, and these choice spirits dedicate their plays to one another in a highly panegyrical manner. Mr. Bazzard has been the subject of one of these dedications. Now, you know, I never had a play dedicated to me!â€
Rosa looked at him as if she would have liked him to be the recipient of a thousand dedications.

â€œWhich again, naturally, rubs against the grain of Mr. Bazzard,â€ said Mr. Grewgious. â€œHe is very short with me sometimes, and then I feel that he is meditating, â€˜This blockhead is my master! A fellow who couldnâ€™t write a tragedy on pain of death, and who will never have one dedicated to him with the most complimentary congratulations on the high position he has taken in the eyes of posterity!â€™ Very trying, very trying. However, in giving him directions, I reflect beforehand: â€˜Perhaps he may not like this,â€™ or â€˜He might take it ill if I asked that;â€™ and so we get on very well. Indeed, better than I could have expected.â€
â€œIs the tragedy named, sir?â€ asked Rosa.

â€œStrictly between ourselves,â€ answered Mr. Grewgious, â€œit has a dreadfully appropriate name. It is called The Thorn of Anxiety. But Mr. Bazzard hopesâ€”and I hopeâ€”that it will come out at last.â€

It was not hard to divine that Mr. Grewgious had related the Bazzard history thus fully, at least quite as much for the recreation of his wardâ€™s mind from the subject that had driven her there, as for the gratification of his own tendency to be social and communicative.

â€œAnd now, my dear,â€ he said at this point, â€œif you are not too tired to tell me more of what passed to-dayâ€”but only if you feel quite ableâ€”I should be glad to hear it. I may digest it the better, if I sleep on it to-night.â€

Rosa, composed now, gave him a faithful account of the interview. Mr. Grewgious often smoothed his head while it was in progress, and begged to be told a second time those parts which bore on Helena and Neville. When Rosa had finished, he sat grave, silent, and meditative for a while.

â€œClearly narrated,â€ was his only remark at last, â€œand, I hope, clearly put away here,â€ smoothing his head again. â€œSee, my dear,â€ taking her to the open window, â€œwhere they live! The dark windows over yonder.â€
â€œI may go to Helena to-morrow?â€ asked Rosa.
â€œI should like to sleep on that question to-night,â€ he answered doubtfully. â€œBut let me take you to your own rest, for you must need it.â€

With that Mr. Grewgious helped her to get her hat on again, and hung upon his arm the very little bag that was of no earthly use, and led her by the hand (with a certain stately awkwardness, as if he were going to walk a minuet) across Holborn, and into Furnivalâ€™s Inn. At the hotel door, he confided her to the Unlimited head chambermaid, and said that while she went up to see her room, he would remain below, in case she should wish it exchanged for another, or should find that there was anything she wanted.

Rosaâ€™s room was airy, clean, comfortable, almost gay. The Unlimited had laid in everything omitted from the very little bag (that is to say, everything she could possibly need), and Rosa tripped down the great many stairs again, to thank her guardian for his thoughtful and affectionate care of her.

â€œNot at all, my dear,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, infinitely gratified; â€œit is I who thank you for your charming confidence and for your charming company. Your breakfast will be provided for you in a neat, compact, and graceful little sitting-room (appropriate to your figure), and I will come to you at ten oâ€™clock in the morning. I hope you donâ€™t feel very strange indeed, in this strange place.â€
â€œO no, I feel so safe!â€
â€œYes, you may be sure that the stairs are fire-proof,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œand that any outbreak of the devouring element would be perceived and suppressed by the watchmen.â€
â€œI did not mean that,â€ Rosa replied. â€œI mean, I feel so safe from him.â€

â€œThere is a stout gate of iron bars to keep him out,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, smiling; â€œand Furnivalâ€™s is fire-proof, and specially watched and lighted, and I live over the way!â€ In the stoutness of his knight-errantry, he seemed to think the last-named protection all sufficient. In the same spirit he said to the gate-porter as he went out, â€œIf some one staying in the hotel should wish to send across the road to me in the night, a crown will be ready for the messenger.â€ In the same spirit, he walked up and down outside the iron gate for the best part of an hour, with some solicitude; occasionally looking in between the bars, as if he had laid a dove in a high roost in a cage of lions, and had it on his mind that she might tumble out.

div.head:
CHAPTER XXI.
A RECOGNITION
div.p: Nothing occurred in the night to flutter the tired dove; and the dove arose refreshed. With Mr. Grewgious, when the clock struck ten in the morning, came Mr. Crisparkle, who had come at one plunge out of the river at Cloisterham.

â€œMiss Twinkleton was so uneasy, Miss Rosa,â€ he explained to her, â€œand came round to Ma and me with your note, in such a state of wonder, that, to quiet her, I volunteered on this service by the very first train to be caught in the morning. I wished at the time that you had come to me; but now I think it best that you did as you did, and came to your guardian.â€
â€œI did think of you,â€ Rosa told him; â€œbut Minor Canon Corner was so near himâ€”â€
â€œI understand. It was quite natural.â€

â€œI have told Mr. Crisparkle,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œall that you told me last night, my dear. Of course I should have written it to him immediately; but his coming was most opportune. And it was particularly kind of him to come, for he had but just gone.â€
â€œHave you settled,â€ asked Rosa, appealing to them both, â€œwhat is to be done for Helena and her brother?â€

â€œWhy really,â€ said Mr. Crisparkle, â€œI am in great perplexity. If even Mr. Grewgious, whose head is much longer than mine, and who is a whole nightâ€™s cogitation in advance of me, is undecided, what must I be!â€

The Unlimited here put her head in at the doorâ€”after having rapped, and been authorised to present herselfâ€”announcing that a gentleman wished for a word with another gentleman named Crisparkle, if any such gentleman were there. If no such gentleman were there, he begged pardon for being mistaken.
â€œSuch a gentleman is here,â€ said Mr. Crisparkle, â€œbut is engaged just now.â€
â€œIs it a dark gentleman?â€ interposed Rosa, retreating on her guardian.
â€œNo, Miss, more of a brown gentleman.â€
â€œYou are sure not with black hair?â€ asked Rosa, taking courage.
â€œQuite sure of that, Miss. Brown hair and blue eyes.â€

â€œPerhaps,â€ hinted Mr. Grewgious, with habitual caution, â€œit might be well to see him, reverend sir, if you donâ€™t object. When one is in a difficulty or at a loss, one never knows in what direction a way out may chance to open. It is a business principle of mine, in such a case, not to close up any direction, but to keep an eye on every direction that may present itself. I could relate an anecdote in point, but that it would be premature.â€
â€œIf Miss Rosa will allow me, then? Let the gentleman come in,â€ said Mr. Crisparkle.
The gentleman came in; apologised, with a frank but modest grace, for not finding Mr. Crisparkle alone; turned to Mr. Crisparkle, and smilingly asked the unexpected question: â€œWho am I?â€
â€œYou are the gentleman I saw smoking under the trees in Staple Inn, a few minutes ago.â€
â€œTrue. There I saw you. Who else am I?â€
Mr. Crisparkle concentrated his attention on a handsome face, much sunburnt; and the ghost of some departed boy seemed to rise, gradually and dimly, in the room.
The gentleman saw a struggling recollection lighten up the Minor Canonâ€™s features, and smiling again, said: â€œWhat will you have for breakfast this morning? You are out of jam.â€
â€œWait a moment!â€ cried Mr. Crisparkle, raising his right hand. â€œGive me another instant! Tartar!â€

The two shook hands with the greatest heartiness, and then went the wonderful lengthâ€”for Englishmenâ€”of laying their hands each on the otherâ€™s shoulders, and looking joyfully each into the otherâ€™s face.
â€œMy old fag!â€ said Mr. Crisparkle.
â€œMy old master!â€ said Mr. Tartar.
â€œYou saved me from drowning!â€ said Mr. Crisparkle.
â€œAfter which you took to swimming, you know!â€ said Mr. Tartar.
â€œGod bless my soul!â€ said Mr. Crisparkle.
â€œAmen!â€ said Mr. Tartar.
And then they fell to shaking hands most heartily again.

â€œImagine,â€ exclaimed Mr. Crisparkle, with glistening eyes: â€œMiss Rosa Bud and Mr. Grewgious, imagine Mr. Tartar, when he was the smallest of juniors, diving for me, catching me, a big heavy senior, by the hair of the head, and striking out for the shore with me like a water-giant!â€

â€œImagine my not letting him sink, as I was his fag!â€ said Mr. Tartar. â€œBut the truth being that he was my best protector and friend, and did me more good than all the masters put together, an irrational impulse seized me to pick him up, or go down with him.â€

â€œHem! Permit me, sir, to have the honour,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, advancing with extended hand, â€œfor an honour I truly esteem it. I am proud to make your acquaintance. I hope you didnâ€™t take cold. I hope you were not inconvenienced by swallowing too much water. How have you been since?â€
It was by no means apparent that Mr. Grewgious knew what he said, though it was very apparent that he meant to say something highly friendly and appreciative.
If Heaven, Rosa thought, had but sent such courage and skill to her poor motherâ€™s aid! And he to have been so slight and young then!

â€œI donâ€™t wish to be complimented upon it, I thank you; but I think I have an idea,â€ Mr. Grewgious announced, after taking a jog-trot or two across the room, so unexpected and unaccountable that they all stared at him, doubtful whether he was choking or had the crampâ€”â€œI think I have an idea. I believe I have had the pleasure of seeing Mr. Tartarâ€™s name as tenant of the top set in the house next the top set in the corner?â€
â€œYes, sir,â€ returned Mr. Tartar. â€œYou are right so far.â€

â€œI am right so far,â€ said Mr. Grewgious. â€œTick that off;â€ which he did, with his right thumb on his left. â€œMight you happen to know the name of your neighbour in the top set on the other side of the party-wall?â€ coming very close to Mr. Tartar, to lose nothing of his face, in his shortness of sight.
â€œLandless.â€
â€œTick that off,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, taking another trot, and then coming back. â€œNo personal knowledge, I suppose, sir?â€
â€œSlight, but some.â€
â€œTick that off,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, taking another trot, and again coming back. â€œNature of knowledge, Mr. Tartar?â€

â€œI thought he seemed to be a young fellow in a poor way, and I asked his leaveâ€”only within a day or soâ€”to share my flowers up there with him; that is to say, to extend my flower-garden to his windows.â€
â€œWould you have the kindness to take seats?â€ said Mr. Grewgious. â€œI have an idea!â€

They complied; Mr. Tartar none the less readily, for being all abroad; and Mr. Grewgious, seated in the centre, with his hands upon his knees, thus stated his idea, with his usual manner of having got the statement by heart.

â€œI cannot as yet make up my mind whether it is prudent to hold open communication under present circumstances, and on the part of the fair member of the present company, with Mr. Neville or Miss Helena. I have reason to know that a local friend of ours (on whom I beg to bestow a passing but a hearty malediction, with the kind permission of my reverend friend) sneaks to and fro, and dodges up and down. When not doing so himself, he may have some informant skulking about, in the person of a watchman, porter, or such-like hanger-on of Staple. On the other hand, Miss Rosa very naturally wishes to see her friend Miss Helena, and it would seem important that at least Miss Helena (if not her brother too, through her) should privately know from Miss Rosaâ€™s lips what has occurred, and what has been threatened. Am I agreed with generally in the views I take?â€
â€œI entirely coincide with them,â€ said Mr. Crisparkle, who had been very attentive.
â€œAs I have no doubt I should,â€ added Mr. Tartar, smiling, â€œif I understood them.â€

â€œFair and softly, sir,â€ said Mr. Grewgious; â€œwe shall fully confide in you directly, if you will favour us with your permission. Now, if our local friend should have any informant on the spot, it is tolerably clear that such informant can only be set to watch the chambers in the occupation of Mr. Neville. He reporting, to our local friend, who comes and goes there, our local friend would supply for himself, from his own previous knowledge, the identity of the parties. Nobody can be set to watch all Staple, or to concern himself with comers and goers to other sets of chambers: unless, indeed, mine.â€
â€œI begin to understand to what you tend,â€ said Mr. Crisparkle, â€œand highly approve of your caution.â€

â€œI neednâ€™t repeat that I know nothing yet of the why and wherefore,â€ said Mr. Tartar; â€œbut I also understand to what you tend, so let me say at once that my chambers are freely at your disposal.â€
â€œThere!â€ cried Mr. Grewgious, smoothing his head triumphantly, â€œnow we have all got the idea. You have it, my dear?â€
â€œI think I have,â€ said Rosa, blushing a little as Mr. Tartar looked quickly towards her.

â€œYou see, you go over to Staple with Mr. Crisparkle and Mr. Tartar,â€ said Mr. Grewgious; â€œI going in and out, and out and in alone, in my usual way; you go up with those gentlemen to Mr. Tartarâ€™s rooms; you look into Mr. Tartarâ€™s flower-garden; you wait for Miss Helenaâ€™s appearance there, or you signify to Miss Helena that you are close by; and you communicate with her freely, and no spy can be the wiser.â€
â€œI am very much afraid I shall beâ€”â€
â€œBe what, my dear?â€ asked Mr. Grewgious, as she hesitated. â€œNot frightened?â€
â€œNo, not that,â€ said Rosa, shyly; â€œin Mr. Tartarâ€™s way. We seem to be appropriating Mr. Tartarâ€™s residence so very coolly.â€
â€œI protest to you,â€ returned that gentleman, â€œthat I shall think the better of it for evermore, if your voice sounds in it only once.â€

Rosa, not quite knowing what to say about that, cast down her eyes, and turning to Mr. Grewgious, dutifully asked if she should put her hat on? Mr. Grewgious being of opinion that she could not do better, she withdrew for the purpose. Mr. Crisparkle took the opportunity of giving Mr. Tartar a summary of the distresses of Neville and his sister; the opportunity was quite long enough, as the hat happened to require a little extra fitting on.
Mr. Tartar gave his arm to Rosa, and Mr. Crisparkle walked, detached, in front.
â€œPoor, poor Eddy!â€ thought Rosa, as they went along.
Mr. Tartar waved his right hand as he bent his head down over Rosa, talking in an animated way.
â€œIt was not so powerful or so sun-browned when it saved Mr. Crisparkle,â€ thought Rosa, glancing at it; â€œbut it must have been very steady and determined even then.â€
Mr. Tartar told her he had been a sailor, roving everywhere for years and years.
â€œWhen are you going to sea again?â€ asked Rosa.
â€œNever!â€

Rosa wondered what the girls would say if they could see her crossing the wide street on the sailorâ€™s arm. And she fancied that the passers-by must think her very little and very helpless, contrasted with the strong figure that could have caught her up and carried her out of any danger, miles and miles without resting.

She was thinking further, that his far-seeing blue eyes looked as if they had been used to watch danger afar off, and to watch it without flinching, drawing nearer and nearer: when, happening to raise her own eyes, she found that he seemed to be thinking something about them.

This a little confused Rosebud, and may account for her never afterwards quite knowing how she ascended (with his help) to his garden in the air, and seemed to get into a marvellous country that came into sudden bloom like the country on the summit of the magic bean-stalk. May it flourish for ever!

div.head:
CHAPTER XXII.
A GRITTY STATE OF THINGS COMES ON
div.p: Mr. Tartarâ€™s chambers were the neatest, the cleanest, and the best-ordered chambers ever seen under the sun, moon, and stars. The floors were scrubbed to that extent, that you might have supposed the London blacks emancipated for ever, and gone out of the land for good. Every inch of brass-work in Mr. Tartarâ€™s possession was polished and burnished, till it shone like a brazen mirror. No speck, nor spot, nor spatter soiled the purity of any of Mr. Tartarâ€™s household gods, large, small, or middle-sized. His sitting-room was like the admiralâ€™s cabin, his bath-room was like a dairy, his sleeping-chamber, fitted all about with lockers and drawers, was like a seedsmanâ€™s shop; and his nicely-balanced cot just stirred in the midst, as if it breathed. Everything belonging to Mr. Tartar had quarters of its own assigned to it: his maps and charts had their quarters; his books had theirs; his brushes had theirs; his boots had theirs; his clothes had theirs; his case-bottles had theirs; his telescopes and other instruments had theirs. Everything was readily accessible. Shelf, bracket, locker, hook, and drawer were equally within reach, and were equally contrived with a view to avoiding waste of room, and providing some snug inches of stowage for something that would have exactly fitted nowhere else. His gleaming little service of plate was so arranged upon his sideboard as that a slack salt-spoon would have instantly betrayed itself; his toilet implements were so arranged upon his dressing-table as that a toothpick of slovenly deportment could have been reported at a glance. So with the curiosities he had brought home from various voyages. Stuffed, dried, repolished, or otherwise preserved, according to their kind; birds, fishes, reptiles, arms, articles of dress, shells, seaweeds, grasses, or memorials of coral reef; each was displayed in its especial place, and each could have been displayed in no better place. Paint and varnish seemed to be kept somewhere out of sight, in constant readiness to obliterate stray finger-marks wherever any might become perceptible in Mr. Tartarâ€™s chambers. No man-of-war was ever kept more spick and span from careless touch. On this bright summer day, a neat awning was rigged over Mr. Tartarâ€™s flower-garden as only a sailor can rig it, and there was a sea-going air upon the whole effect, so delightfully complete, that the flower-garden might have appertained to stern-windows afloat, and the whole concern might have bowled away gallantly with all on board, if Mr. Tartar had only clapped to his lips the speaking-trumpet that was slung in a corner, and given hoarse orders to heave the anchor up, look alive there, men, and get all sail upon her!

Mr. Tartar doing the honours of this gallant craft was of a piece with the rest. When a man rides an amiable hobby that shies at nothing and kicks nobody, it is only agreeable to find him riding it with a humorous sense of the droll side of the creature. When the man is a cordial and an earnest man by nature, and withal is perfectly fresh and genuine, it may be doubted whether he is ever seen to greater advantage than at such a time. So Rosa would have naturally thought (even if she hadnâ€™t been conducted over the ship with all the homage due to the First Lady of the Admiralty, or First Fairy of the Sea), that it was charming to see and hear Mr. Tartar half laughing at, and half rejoicing in, his various contrivances. So Rosa would have naturally thought, anyhow, that the sunburnt sailor showed to great advantage when, the inspection finished, he delicately withdrew out of his admiralâ€™s cabin, beseeching her to consider herself its Queen, and waving her free of his flower-garden with the hand that had had Mr. Crisparkleâ€™s life in it.
â€œHelena! Helena Landless! Are you there?â€
â€œWho speaks to me? Not Rosa?â€ Then a second handsome face appearing.
â€œYes, my darling!â€
â€œWhy, how did you come here, dearest?â€
â€œIâ€”I donâ€™t quite know,â€ said Rosa with a blush; â€œunless I am dreaming!â€
Why with a blush? For their two faces were alone with the other flowers. Are blushes among the fruits of the country of the magic bean-stalk?
â€œI am not dreaming,â€ said Helena, smiling. â€œI should take more for granted if I were. How do we come togetherâ€”or so near togetherâ€”so very unexpectedly?â€

Unexpectedly indeed, among the dingy gables and chimney-pots of P. J. T.â€s connection, and the flowers that had sprung from the salt sea. But Rosa, waking, told in a hurry how they came to be together, and all the why and wherefore of that matter.
â€œAnd Mr. Crisparkle is here,â€ said Rosa, in rapid conclusion; â€œand, could you believe it? long ago he saved his life!â€
â€œI could believe any such thing of Mr. Crisparkle,â€ returned Helena, with a mantling face.
(More blushes in the bean-stalk country!)
â€œYes, but it wasnâ€™t Crisparkle,â€ said Rosa, quickly putting in the correction.
â€œI donâ€™t understand, love.â€
â€œIt was very nice of Mr. Crisparkle to be saved,â€ said Rosa, â€œand he couldnâ€™t have shown his high opinion of Mr. Tartar more expressively. But it was Mr. Tartar who saved him.â€
Helenaâ€™s dark eyes looked very earnestly at the bright face among the leaves, and she asked, in a slower and more thoughtful tone:
â€œIs Mr. Tartar with you now, dear?â€
â€œNo; because he has given up his rooms to meâ€”to us, I mean. It is such a beautiful place!â€
â€œIs it?â€
â€œIt is like the inside of the most exquisite ship that ever sailed. It is likeâ€”it is likeâ€”â€
â€œLike a dream?â€ suggested Helena.
Rosa answered with a little nod, and smelled the flowers.

Helena resumed, after a short pause of silence, during which she seemed (or it was Rosaâ€™s fancy) to compassionate somebody: â€œMy poor Neville is reading in his own room, the sun being so very bright on this side just now. I think he had better not know that you are so near.â€
â€œO, I think so too!â€ cried Rosa very readily.

â€œI suppose,â€ pursued Helena, doubtfully, â€œthat he must know by-and-by all you have told me; but I am not sure. Ask Mr. Crisparkleâ€™s advice, my darling. Ask him whether I may tell Neville as much or as little of what you have told me as I think best.â€
Rosa subsided into her state-cabin, and propounded the question. The Minor Canon was for the free exercise of Helenaâ€™s judgment.

â€œI thank him very much,â€ said Helena, when Rosa emerged again with her report. â€œAsk him whether it would be best to wait until any more maligning and pursuing of Neville on the part of this wretch shall disclose itself, or to try to anticipate it: I mean, so far as to find out whether any such goes on darkly about us?â€

The Minor Canon found this point so difficult to give a confident opinion on, that, after two or three attempts and failures, he suggested a reference to Mr. Grewgious. Helena acquiescing, he betook himself (with a most unsuccessful assumption of lounging indifference) across the quadrangle to P. J. T.â€s, and stated it. Mr. Grewgious held decidedly to the general principle, that if you could steal a march upon a brigand or a wild beast, you had better do it; and he also held decidedly to the special case, that John Jasper was a brigand and a wild beast in combination.
Thus advised, Mr. Crisparkle came back again and reported to Rosa, who in her turn reported to Helena. She now steadily pursuing her train of thought at her window, considered thereupon.
â€œWe may count on Mr. Tartarâ€™s readiness to help us, Rosa?â€ she inquired.

O yes! Rosa shyly thought so. O yes, Rosa shyly believed she could almost answer for it. But should she ask Mr. Crisparkle? â€œI think your authority on the point as good as his, my dear,â€ said Helena, sedately, â€œand you neednâ€™t disappear again for that.â€ Odd of Helena!

â€œYou see, Neville,â€ Helena pursued after more reflection, â€œknows no one else here: he has not so much as exchanged a word with any one else here. If Mr. Tartar would call to see him openly and often; if he would spare a minute for the purpose, frequently; if he would even do so, almost daily; something might come of it.â€
â€œSomething might come of it, dear?â€ repeated Rosa, surveying her friendâ€™s beauty with a highly perplexed face. â€œSomething might?â€

â€œIf Nevilleâ€™s movements are really watched, and if the purpose really is to isolate him from all friends and acquaintance and wear his daily life out grain by grain (which would seem to be the threat to you), does it not appear likely,â€ said Helena, â€œthat his enemy would in some way communicate with Mr. Tartar to warn him off from Neville? In which case, we might not only know the fact, but might know from Mr. Tartar what the terms of the communication were.â€
â€œI see!â€ cried Rosa. And immediately darted into her state-cabin again.

Presently her pretty face reappeared, with a greatly heightened colour, and she said that she had told Mr. Crisparkle, and that Mr. Crisparkle had fetched in Mr. Tartar, and that Mr. Tartarâ€”â€œwho is waiting now, in case you want him,â€ added Rosa, with a half look back, and in not a little confusion between the inside of the state-cabin and outâ€”had declared his readiness to act as she had suggested, and to enter on his task that very day.
â€œI thank him from my heart,â€ said Helena. â€œPray tell him so.â€

Again not a little confused between the Flower-garden and the Cabin, Rosa dipped in with her message, and dipped out again with more assurances from Mr. Tartar, and stood wavering in a divided state between Helena and him, which proved that confusion is not always necessarily awkward, but may sometimes present a very pleasant appearance.
â€œAnd now, darling,â€ said Helena, â€œwe will be mindful of the caution that has restricted us to this interview for the present, and will part. I hear Neville moving too. Are you going back?â€
â€œTo Miss Twinkletonâ€™s?â€ asked Rosa.
â€œYes.â€
â€œO, I could never go there any more. I couldnâ€™t indeed, after that dreadful interview!â€ said Rosa.
â€œThen where are you going, pretty one?â€
â€œNow I come to think of it, I donâ€™t know,â€ said Rosa. â€œI have settled nothing at all yet, but my guardian will take care of me. Donâ€™t be uneasy, dear. I shall be sure to be somewhere.â€
(It did seem likely.)
â€œAnd I shall hear of my Rosebud from Mr. Tartar?â€ inquired Helena.

â€œYes, I suppose so; fromâ€”â€ Rosa looked back again in a flutter, instead of supplying the name. â€œBut tell me one thing before we part, dearest Helena. Tell meâ€”that you are sure, sure, sure, I couldnâ€™t help it.â€
â€œHelp it, love?â€
â€œHelp making him malicious and revengeful. I couldnâ€™t hold any terms with him, could I?â€
â€œYou know how I love you, darling,â€ answered Helena, with indignation; â€œbut I would sooner see you dead at his wicked feet.â€
â€œThatâ€™s a great comfort to me! And you will tell your poor brother so, wonâ€™t you? And you will give him my remembrance and my sympathy? And you will ask him not to hate me?â€

With a mournful shake of the head, as if that would be quite a superfluous entreaty, Helena lovingly kissed her two hands to her friend, and her friendâ€™s two hands were kissed to her; and then she saw a third hand (a brown one) appear among the flowers and leaves, and help her friend out of sight.

The refection that Mr. Tartar produced in the Admiralâ€™s Cabin by merely touching the spring knob of a locker and the handle of a drawer, was a dazzling enchanted repast. Wonderful macaroons, glittering liqueurs, magically-preserved tropical spices, and jellies of celestial tropical fruits, displayed themselves profusely at an instantâ€™s notice. But Mr. Tartar could not make time stand still; and time, with his hard-hearted fleetness, strode on so fast, that Rosa was obliged to come down from the bean-stalk country to earth and her guardianâ€™s chambers.
â€œAnd now, my dear,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œwhat is to be done next? To put the same thought in another form; what is to be done with you?â€

Rosa could only look apologetically sensible of being very much in her own way and in everybody elseâ€™s. Some passing idea of living, fireproof, up a good many stairs in Furnivalâ€™s Inn for the rest of her life, was the only thing in the nature of a plan that occurred to her.

â€œIt has come into my thoughts,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œthat as the respected lady, Miss Twinkleton, occasionally repairs to London in the recess, with the view of extending her connection, and being available for interviews with metropolitan parents, if anyâ€”whether, until we have time in which to turn ourselves round, we might invite Miss Twinkleton to come and stay with you for a month?â€
â€œStay where, sir?â€
â€œWhether,â€ explained Mr. Grewgious, â€œwe might take a furnished lodging in town for a month, and invite Miss Twinkleton to assume the charge of you in it for that period?â€
â€œAnd afterwards?â€ hinted Rosa.
â€œAnd afterwards,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, â€œwe should be no worse off than we are now.â€
â€œI think that might smooth the way,â€ assented Rosa.

â€œThen let us,â€ said Mr. Grewgious, rising, â€œgo and look for a furnished lodging. Nothing could be more acceptable to me than the sweet presence of last evening, for all the remaining evenings of my existence; but these are not fit surroundings for a young lady. Let us set out in quest of adventures, and look for a furnished lodging. In the meantime, Mr. Crisparkle here, about to return home immediately, will no doubt kindly see Miss Twinkleton, and invite that lady to co-operate in our plan.â€
Mr. Crisparkle, willingly accepting the commission, took his departure; Mr. Grewgious and his ward set forth on their expedition.

As Mr. Grewgiousâ€™s idea of looking at a furnished lodging was to get on the opposite side of the street to a house with a suitable bill in the window, and stare at it; and then work his way tortuously to the back of the house, and stare at that; and then not go in, but make similar trials of another house, with the same result; their progress was but slow.
